summary: Manuel Marti was the subject of a U.S. Army background investigation in 1968 and 1969 to determine his suitability for a position of trust and his retention in the Army. The investigation involved checks with the FBI, New York City Police Department, credit agencies, and interviews with neighbors, former co-workers, and character references in the Bronx, New York. These checks aimed to verify his background, employment history, education, and character. The investigation also looked into his family, including his father, Adrian Sotomayor (later Manuel Marti), and siblings, Ivan and Blanca Marti. A key aspect of the investigation involved verifying Marti's birth records, which revealed a name change from Manuel Adrian Sotomayor-Badillo, and his father's name change. The investigation concluded favorably, recommending the closure of his case under AR 604-10, though it was noted that this did not automatically qualify him for a security clearance. In 1969, while serving in Vietnam, Marti provided a sworn statement affirming his allegiance to the United States and denying any communist affiliations. The Army ultimately concurred that his retention was consistent with national security interests.
significance: The documents suggest Manuel Marti was being vetted for a position of trust with the U.S. government and his background was being investigated by the U.S. Army. The documents do not directly link Manuel Marti to the JFK assassination. The investigation appears to be a routine background check, focusing on his personal history, family, and associations to assess his loyalty and suitability for military service and a potential position of trust.
